More importantly, the other matter of great concern is the application of politics in general to the sugar industry, which is a move I deplore. I refer to the recent closure of the Goondi mill. I note that the Minister on 19 March denied any involvement whatsoever. His media release stated:

Legislation rushed through the Queensland Parliament on Tuesday night to provide rationalisation of sugar milling in the Far North sugar region of Queensland was entirely a Queensland Government action, the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin, said today.
On 10 December 1986 he put out a media release that stated:

The Commonwealth has agreed to provide $4.6 million for the Sugar Milling Adjustment Committee's proposed sugar mill merger plan for the Goondi, Mourilyan and Babinda areas, the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin, announced today.

Shocked sugar growers who supplied Goondi mill in North Queensland protested loudly yesterday at the `politics' of Queensland and Federal Governments alike after waking up to find their mill had been closed overnight by legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sugar Cane Levy Bill and the Sugar Cane Levy Collection Bill are similar in content to research Acts already in operation for other rural industries such as grain, legumes and cotton. The legislation provides for the imposition and collection of a levy on growers and millers of sugar cane to finance the research scheme. The levy will be applied to sugar cane delivered and accepted by a raw sugar mill for milling on or after 1 June 1987. In a letter dated 8 September 1985 from the Queensland Cane Growers Council to the Proprietary Sugar Millers Association Pty Ltd, it was noted that the Queensland Cane Growers Council had resolved:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Queensland Cane Growers Council endorse the action of its Chairman in joining with the other sugar industry associations in an approach to the Commonwealth Government for establishment of a Sugar Industry Rural Industry Research Fund under circumstances in which the Council:
(i) indicates support from all sections of the cane growing industry;
(ii) agrees to an initial levy of 5c per tonne of cane to be paid on a dollar for dollar basis by cane growers and millowners;
(iii) advises the Commonwealth that the industry's current administrative approach to levy funding is the most cost-effective system; and
(iv) agrees that the Sugar Industry RIRF legislation contain provision for millowners to collect and forward to the Commonwealth the growers' half of the total levy in each.
It is also pertinent to add that the sugar industry working party established a few years ago recommended:

. . . that the sugar industry enter into discussions with the Commonwealth Government at an early opportunity with a view to securing additional funding, under arrangements similar to those which apply to the wheat and barley industries and that the Commonwealth Government respond favourably to these representations.

Last year the Queensland sugar industry associations, with the support of the New South Wales Cane Growers Association and the New South Wales Co-operative Sugar Milling Association, wrote to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) seeking to have established a rural industry research fund to operate from the 1987-88 year and which would coincide with the sugar industry crop year. The associations suggested that the fund be based on an industry levy of the order of 5c per tonne of cane. The levies would be paid by cane growers and sugar mills and reflect the joint interests of both cane growers and sugar millers in agricultural research.

The sugar industry has in place an efficient system for the collection and payment of levies through the mills. The associations proposed that this system be utilised for the purpose of collecting the rural industry research fund levy. Furthermore, the associations indicated to the Minister that they were aware of the provisions of the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 relating to rural industry research funds, including the establishment of a research industry council by a selection committee. The industry's associations said that they were prepared to nominate people for these committees and that they hoped the necessary legislation for the sugar industry research committee could be established as soon as possible.

The Rural Industries Research Act was introduced in 1985 by the Hawke Government, an authentic Australian government. Omnibus legislation provided administrative and organisational arrangements for the establishment of research funds by rural industries. These Bills complement the Rural Industries Research Act and thus will establish a sugar industry research fund. These Bills provide for an initial levy of 5c per tonne of cane-that is 2.5c for the miller and 2.5c for the grower-to be applied to all cane supplied after 1 June 1987. When matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth, this levy will put $2.5m annually into the sugar industry research fund for cane and sugar research to be controlled by a sugar cane research council comprising representatives from the sugar industry, State and Federal primary industry departments and senior researchers from such organisations as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisations, universities and colleges of advanced education.

The possible advantages of the resolution passed by the Queensland Cane Growers Council in 1985, which I mentioned previously, were reviewed by the Council. The Council noted that a rural industry research fund would provide more funds for industry research at a lower industry cost. Sugar industry research organisations would have an opportunity to obtain a share of the research moneys generated by a rural industry research fund which would help to limit any levy increases, particularly at a time of increasing cost pressures. Wider exposure would be gained through the contribution of outside research bodies, which could benefit the industry. The need to compete for research funds could provide a performance stimulus for sugar industry research organisations. Above all, the rural industry research fund requirement for longer term research planning would promote better accountability, one of the central tenets of the 1985 legislation. In addition, there could be savings for sugar industry research organisations in that funds which they now provide to outside research institutions should be provided to rural industry research funds.

Mr E. H. Churchward, the cane growers representative on the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations Board, has canvassed very thoroughly the history of sugar cane research. Mr Churchward has observed that over the past 30 to 40 years the most obvious changes in the Queensland sugar industry have been growth in size and improved levels of productivity. For example, in 1950, 894,000 tonnes of raw sugar were produced from 104,200 hectares. By 1984 production had increased to 3.35 million tonnes of raw sugar from 297,800 hectares. That is an increase of 275 per cent in sugar production from an area increase of 185 per cent. This indicates that 66 per cent of the increase in production for the period was due to the increase in area and 34 per cent of the increase was due to adoption of new technology. This is equivalent to an increase in production of 0.8 per cent per annum and, on present low values of raw sugar, amounts to approximately $6m.

The sugar industry's system of payment, Mr Churchward observed, has built-in incentives to encourage the adoption of research findings. The system gives bonuses to the grower for supplying cane with high sugar contents and the mills reap additional benefits as their efficiency in the recovery of sugar increases. It is believed that these factors over the years have played an important role in fostering the sugar industry's commitment to financing its own research. Mr Churchward further observed that the sugar industry has long recognised the benefits of research and development, as indicated by its willingness to fund its own research. Cane growers and raw sugar millers have funded the majority of the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations research since its formation in 1900 and the millers have funded the Sugar Research Institute. The Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations is a statutory authority established in 1900 and financed principally by the Queensland sugar industry from a levy paid on each tonne of cane harvested.

The Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations conducts research into cane growing and, to a lesser extent, research into sugar milling. Until recently the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations had a relatively large team of scientists researching various aspects of milling, but these programs have been rationalised following the recommendation of the sugar industry 100-day working party, to which I referred earlier. In some instances the research has been transferred to the Sugar Research Institute at Mackay in the electorate of the honourable member for Dawson.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! A good research institute, too.

—Indeed it is. Mr Churchward said that it is recognised that the sugar industry has enjoyed significant benefits from its research through increased productivity and the solving of major productivity problems. Consequently, despite the current low world prices for sugar, the industry has endeavoured to maintain a significant research effort to maintain its competitive advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations operates on an annual Budget of approximately $6m, funded in the main from an assessment of 19.2c per tonne of cane delivered to mills in Queensland, on a fifty-fifty basis between grower and mill owner. Other sources of funds include grants-for example, that by the State Government of approximately $680,000-and sales of cane grown on the various experiment stations. In recent years the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations has also received research grants-for example, from the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council program-for ethanol related research, and from the Sugar Board for research into sugar quality matters.

The Tully Co-operative Sugar Milling Association Ltd has played a significant role in developing ethanol related research and urging governments, both Federal and State, to participate in ethanol related research. I take this opportunity to call on the Federal Government to encourage ethanol related research, either by way of direct grant or under the present scheme of funding for rural industry research activities. I think it is a most important project. A country such as Australia, with the technology available to it, should be able to match with ease the production methods and techniques of production being used at present in Brazil.

Sugar Research Ltd is also supported in the main by an annual levy, but only from mill owners. Since 1967 the Federal Government has paid Sugar Research Ltd a grant through the CSIRO for research into raw sugar milling and associated activities. Although initally these grants were for five-yearly periods, since 1980 the grant has been approved on a yearly basis and in 1981 administration of the grant was transferred to the Department of Science.

I would like to mention some particular research projects that are relevant to the production of sugar cane in north Queensland. A major discovery in north Queensland was the discovery in 1949 of ratoon stunting disease and the subsequent development of heat treatment to produce disease-free planting material. The disease is insidious, with no obvious symptoms, but can cause significant losses in yield. Furthermore, the upsurge of Fiji disease in south Queensland in the late 1960s led to one of the most serious disease outbreaks ever seen in the Queensland sugar industry. The planting of resistant varieties brought the outbreak under control, but without research into developing resistant varieties the sugar industry in south Queensland would have been seriously threatened with economic disaster.

Since 1980 an intensive research program has been undertaken by a multi-disciplinary team of Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations scientists to determine the cause of poorly developed root systems of sugar cane in the high rainfall cane growing areas of north Queensland. The problem is known as poor root syndrome and is found in the area from Cairns to Tully. More recently it has been located in cane in the Mackay region.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. We do not get enough rain for that.

—I take note of what the honourable member for Dawson has said. Cane with affected root systems is easily lifted out of the soil and readily blown over by wind and rain, causing harvesting, milling and ratooning problems. There is strong evidence of the poor root syndrome, particularly in the Tully area, which I have inspected, which creates enormous problems for cane growers in regard to cane being blown over and suffering root damage. Problems are also encountered during harvesting and by the miller in treating the cane and separating the sugar from extraneous matter. Two fungal pathogens, one of which was previously unknown, are the major factors responsible for extensive soft rotting of roots. Researchers have developed a glasshouse technique to screen varieties for resistance. Advanced varieties in the north Queensland cane selection program are now routinely tested.

SPEECH.PARA: The scope of research undertaken by the team involved in poor root syndrome studies has been widened to include investigations of the cause of yield decline through continuous cropping of sugar cane. Improved crop growth after soil has been fumigated and improved yields in parts of fields which have been extended into adjacent new land or headlands are both considered to indicate that such yield decline occurs. Estimates of yield responses of about 100 per cent have been noted when new land is brought into production, compared with the yield obtained on old land. It is obvious that only through research will the mechanism of yield decline be elucidated.

While much of the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations research is aimed primarily at increasing productivity, some of the gains have been negated by losses of cane during harvesting. Since 1977 research has been carried out on harvester systems which remove extraneous matter from the cane supply. Initial field tests showed that losses were in the order of 2 to 13 per cent. Subsequently, a testing facility was constructed with the co-operation of harvester manufacturers, Massey-Ferguson (Australia) Ltd and Versatile Toft Ltd. This facility enabled more definitive testing to be undertaken on chopping and cleaning systems in harvesters. It was shown that the equivalent of 2.5 per cent of cane was lost in the chopping of cane into billets and up to 3 to 4 per cent was discarded by way of the extractor fans during the cleaning process. In the Herbert River district in part of my electorate, and also in the electorate of Kennedy, there is a concentrated effort to ensure that harvesting techniques are properly managed so that the maximum quantity of sugar can be retained in the billets that have been harvested.

There is no doubt that the sugar industry owes much to research and development for its competitive position. However, much more research is required to maintain the competitive edge. Previously, the industry had the financial resources to pay for its own research and development. But in recent times the poor returns from export markets has seriously eroded the capacity of the industry to pay. To overcome this problem the industry is currently seeking to establish a rural industry research fund so that much needed financial support for research and development can be obtained from the Commonwealth. These Bills are in response to those inquiries from the cane growing industry. The sugar industry has a long and distinguished record of research and development which has been of considerable benefit to it. The outlook for the industry is dependent not only on the marketing of its products and efficient production but also on its ability to support research and development capacity.

I congratulate the Minister for Primary Industry, who has been conscientious and determined to ensure that an industry which is a major component of Australia's export capacity receives the proper research funding that is necessary if it is to continue to assist in providing a high standard of living in Australia. The Minister for Primary Industry was responsible for the introduction of the Rural Industry Research Act in 1985 and for the setting up of various councils responsible for the various industries. I share with the Cane Growers Council and other members of the sugar associations in Australia their full confidence that this package of legislation will provide the sugar industry of Australia with a much needed boost to research and development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) intends to move an amendment to the legislation before us. Although the National Party of Australia does not intend to oppose that amendment, we would like to put on notice the fact that it will have been properly considered by the time the legislation reaches the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sugar Cane Levy Bill and the Sugar Cane Levy Collection Bill are probably the initial result of an Industries Assistance Commission report in June 1976 which made a recommendation in respect of the research facilities available to rural industries. This was followed in the 1980s by the report of the Balderstone Working Group to Provide a Policy Discussion Paper on Agriculture which included rural research as part of its major recommendations. A working party of the sugar industry-the 100-day report committee-made two recommendations in this regard. The report stated:

The Working Party considers that the industry's research effort must be maintained and strengthened through improved organisation arrangements and additional funding from the Commonwealth Government under its rural research program.
It went on to state:

The Working Party recommends that the sugar industry enter into discussions with the Commonwealth Government at an early opportunity with a view to securing additional funding, under arrangements similar to those which apply to the wheat and barley industries, and that the Commonwealth Government respond favour- ably to these representations.

We now see all of those efforts of the last 10 years coming to fruition. Levies will be collected for use by the sugar industry research council. Contributions will be made by millers, growers and the Commonwealth under the guidelines of the Rural Industries Research Act 1985. The administrative framework for the research council and the selection committee was established under the Rural Industries Research Act, but the Bills now before us are now needed to formalise levy collections. The levy will be struck on sugar cane and matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of industry production. The industry contribution will be shared, initially on a 50:50 basis between growers and millers. Levies will be struck initially at 5c per tonne of sugar cane delivered and accepted by a raw sugar mill for milling but the legislation sets a maximum levy of 10c. Provision is made for the 50:50 split between grower and miller to be varied by the Minister in consultation with the industry.

Under normal seasonal conditions, the levy will raise some $1.25m, so the annual research effort should approach $2m. Although a full year program will not begin until 1988-89, the levy will be struck from 1 June this year, which may enable some preliminary research to begin in 1987-88. Some doubt has been expressed within the industry as to when the actual research will commence, bearing in mind that the levy will commence on 1 June. The Minister for Primary Industry might oblige the House and the National Party by assuring us that these funds will be made available at the earliest opportunity to allow the research to commence. There is a suggestion that the research funds will take the place of some of the subsidies or grants that are already made available to the industry. I am particularly thinking of the funds made available to the Sugar Research Institute through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Of course, the legislation begs the question that is often in the minds of many people about the sugar industry being very highly subsidised. Of course, this view is contrary to the facts. However, it is unfortunate that the ill-informed opinion prevails that the sugar industry is highly subsidised.

The research effort which is the subject of this legislation is only a small part of the research that is already carried out. These levies may in some part reduce future increases in existing levies. For instance, cane farmers and millers already contribute 19.2c per tonne to the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations. Cane pest and disease control costs another 8c per tonne. Sugar millers pay 8c per tonne to the Sugar Research Institute. In the 1986 season the cost of self-help programs already provided within the industry amounted to approximately $8.5m. This is quite apart from the levies that are paid additionally as part of their organisational commitments. The sugar industry must be one of the last industries to have sought funding relief from the Commonwealth. The Queensland Government makes a contribution of $803,000 towards sugar research, while the Commonwealth makes a contribution of $580,000. As I mentioned earlier, it is my hope that the additional research funds proposed will not relieve the Commonwealth Government of its present commitment in this respect.

It has to be said that the sugar industry survives solely by efficiency and increased productivity, which it alone provides. Eighty per cent of sugar production is sold on the world market. Some is subject to long term contract but most is sold on the open market where the price at the moment is a shade short of 7c a pound. The industry contributes 20 per cent of its production to the domestic market. While I have to say that the industry enjoys a preferential price on the domestic market as compared with the open market, this arrangement allows it to maintain a place in the world market. It has been claimed that the industry is receiving a preference or consumer subsidy in respect of the domestic market. Over the last 10 years it has been estimated within the industry that the consumers of Australia have benefited to the extent of over $400m because the world price has at times fluctuated below and above the set domestic price. The sugar industry of Australia has subsidised the consumers of Australia to the extent of over $400m.

It is sometimes claimed that in the current trade and pricing environment for Australia's primary industries the sugar embargo is a direct subsidy paid by the Australian consumer against the low world price. Perhaps that is correct if looked at in the light of today's prices. However, as I have just mentioned, there has been a subsidy of $408m to the Australian consumers. An Industries Assistance Commission report on assistance to Australian agriculture puts the myth of protection into its proper prospective. That report indicates that assistance to sugar growing in 1970-71 was 38 per cent. Within two years, assistance decreased to 13 per cent and a further two years later it was minus 19 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was indicating the type of assistance that had been given to the sugar industry. I quoted from an Industries Assistance Commission report which indicated that sugar grown in 1970-71 was given 38 per cent support, within two years assistance decreased to 13 per cent and two years later assistance was minus 19 per cent. By 1980-81 it stood at minus 13 per cent-so much for the subsidisation of this industry. In overall terms, primary industry had an effective protection rate of 8 per cent. In 1970 it had been 28 per cent. Today, manufacturing industry has an effective protection rate of 24 per cent. This is only 12 per cent lower than the 1970 figure of 36 per cent. So the suggestion that the sugar industry is heavily subsidised is a myth, proved by those figures.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to do now is compare the positions that our sugar competitors overseas face. Production of United States of America farmers is subsidised to an extent of over 18c a pound. This is three times the world price. Within the last six months Australia's quota to the United States has been drastically reduced to 75,000 tonnes. Over a period of years, Australian industry has adjusted to this decrease, but it is indicated quite clearly in what I just mentioned that the effect of that subsidy will be to increase production in the United States. We fear that within a short time the Americans will be exporters and not importers. In fact, the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) in a statement on 16 December 1986 said:
It is ominous that Secretary Lyng forecast in his statement that if current trends continue-
that is, in the United States-
in another two years the existing sugar program will make the United States self sufficient in sweetener production for the first time in history.

That will have a consequence for Australian industry but the industry in the past has been able to accommodate such problems. What is the reality of this subsidy in the United States? Who have been the losers? A special document has been prepared on behalf of the Australian sugar industry which identifies the losers from the United States sugar policy as follows: First the United States consumer who paid a premium of $15 billion during the last five years to support domestic sugar producers; secondly, the United States taxpayers who have paid $85m to subsidise losses on sales of forfeited United States production; thirdly, the United States sugar refiners who have closed nine of the 23 cane sugar refineries since 1981; and, fourthly, foreign suppliers to the United States, such as Australia. By 1986, the net benefit to them of higher prices in the United States market had been eroded as a result of massive reductions in the import quota and a subsequent erosion of the world free market price for sugar. That is the situation in the United States.

It is interesting that the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) and the Minister for Primary Industry were part of a parliamentary delegation on wheat sales to the United States Congress last year. It has been suggested on more than one occasion that a similar delegation should have been undertaken on the sugar situation by parliamentarians. It is too late to do much good but a belated delegation will go to the United States this month or next month.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without a Minister?
—As I understand it, the Minister is not even going to Washington to be part of that delegation. That is where the point has to be made, before congressmen of the United States.
—But the Deputy Leader of the National Party is going.

—Yes, or perhaps the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) could go. It is interesting that had that delegation visited the United States at a suitable time it could have been enhanced and enriched by sugar producer representatives. Mr John Andrew, the Chairman of the Sugar Board, and Mr Roy Deicke, President of the Proprietary Sugar Millers Association and Mr Fred Soper of the Queensland Cane Growers Council undertook, at their own expense, a recent visit to the United States. I understand that they have come back feeling that the quota the Minister mentioned in his December statement is very much under threat. As I said, the Australian industry has adjusted to a quota from a peak of well over 200,000 tonnes to what it is now. But this is an indication of what the massive subsidies in the United States are doing.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the problem of the European Economic Community on which a Bureau of Agricultural Economics report about 18 months ago suggested that because of subsidies there is a $1 billion loss to Australian farmers. That was an excellent BAE report. Unfortunately, there were not sufficient funds to go forward and make that publication available within the EEC. I understand that the effective subsidy on sugar in the European Community is over $400 per tonne. A recent survey was taken of the agricultural policy of the European Community which indicated that the European Community sugar arrangements are estimated to result in the level of EC production being 1.3 to 2.3 million tonnes higher and exports being 1.6 to 2.5 million tonnes higher than if no arrangements for subsidies existed. The survey also indicated that levy rates applying before 1981-82 had the long run effect of depressing the world free market price for sugar by 7 to 12 per cent while rates applying after 1981-82 reduced prices by 5 to 11 per cent. Obviously, that has resulted in the dreadfully low price in world markets today.

The survey also indicated that if the community did not support its sugar industry, sugar exports of other countries would be an average of one million tonnes a year or 7 per cent higher in the long term. The cost to the Australian economy as a result of the European Community sugar support regime with the levy rates applying prior to 1981-82 was between $US95m and $US150m in 1982 values. With the higher European Community levy rates since 1981-82 this cost to Australian farmers is now estimated to be between $US72m and $US139m. When we compare assistance to Australian industry with what has happened overseas and the consequences, we can easily relate that to the fact that the Australian sugar farmer and sugar miller has to be efficient, productive and innovative to relate to this world.

I will now consider Brazil's situation in the world market. Brazil has the ability to transfer its sugar production into ethanol as it can dictate to its market on whether it is better to offset fuel imports by conversion to ethanol or sell sugar on the overseas market. There is a need through this research legislation for Australia to make that move to alternative fuel production of ethanol whenever the need might arise. Self-sufficiency in fuel is decreasing from 100 per cent at the moment. There is nothing surer than that under the policies of this Government this figure will decrease further. It is interesting to note that Brazil is able to supply 40 per cent of its fuel requirements through changing sugar into ethanol. I believe, as was indicated by the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) earlier, that there should be vigorous research in this area to make that conversion.

Australian farmers and millers and the sugar industry are not subsidised. They have no alternative but to trade in the world market and can do so only on the basis of efficiency. The Australian sugar industry contributes $600m annually to export income. This figure truly reflects the net foreign exchange benefits to Australia through this industry. It still plays a very important part in world trade as far as Australia's requirements are concerned.

Part of the package that this research is attached to was also part of an underwriting of the sugar price of $230 for the 1986 season. It is interesting to note that the trigger for that support price will not be reached in either the 1986 season or the following season. Thus, there has been no assistance from that package, except in the first year. Funds have been made available for mill rationalisation. I understand that Bundaberg has rationalised its industry to some extent by amalgamating two mill areas into one. Goondi will now transfer to Mourilyan and Babinda with assistance from rationalisation, but the Mackay mill proposal, which was voted on at the beginning of this year, unfortunately failed. Had it succeeded it would have been part of that rationalisation. There is also an interest subsidy area so that farmers faced with high interest rates which are well above those originally contracted can get some relief and debt reconstruction.

This Bill is little enough return for what this Government has done to the sugar industry and other primary industries over the past four years. I mention once again the high tax factor and high interest rates. These have had a material effect on the fortunes of the industry over the last four years. The propped up dollar does not allow the industry to reap its just rewards on international markets. I also suggest that the Bill is a poor return for the imposition of fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax, the assets test and also the fact that income equalisation deposits have been gutted to such an extent that they are of very little use to any industry in the primary industry sector. In this regard the industry has had many uphill battles. I believe it has won many of them and the support of the levy at this stage will be most welcome.

I also mention the alternative effect of government policies, particularly in the health area. The Commonwealth Department of Health seems to be determined to put sugar on the endangered species list whereas the Minister for Primary Industry, who is at the table, has spent so much of his own time trying to promote the product. Our Department of Health seems to find great delight in decrying the sugar industry at every point. The National Party supports this Bill as it is something for which the industry has asked, but comments relating to the amount of reward given to it from the point of view of the levy and the expense incurred by the industry should be noted.
